TITLE: Implementing a GTK 4 Application with Event Handlers in Rust
DESCRIPTION: An example demonstrating how to set up a GTK application with user interface elements and event handlers. This shows application initialization, window creation, adding a button with a click handler, and running the main event loop.

```
use gtk4 as gtk;
use gtk::prelude::*;
use gtk::{glib, Application, ApplicationWindow, Button};

fn main() -> glib::ExitCode {
    let application = Application::builder()
        .application_id("com.example.FirstGtkApp")
        .build();

    application.connect_activate(|app| {
        let window = ApplicationWindow::builder()
            .application(app)
            .title("First GTK Program")
            .default_width(350)
            .default_height(70)
            .build();

        let button = Button::with_label("Click me!");
        button.connect_clicked(|_| {
            eprintln!("Clicked!");
        });
        window.set_child(Some(&button));

        window.present();
    });

    application.run()
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Custom Button State and Click Handling (Rust)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet modifies the `CustomButton` implementation struct to include a `number` state using `RefCell<u64>` for interior mutability. It overrides the `constructed` method from `ObjectImpl` to initialize the button label using the state. It also overrides the `clicked` method from `ButtonImpl` to increment the number and update the label on each click, adding custom behavior to the button.
SOURCE: https://github.com/gtk-rs/gtk4-rs/blob/main/book/src/g_object_subclassing.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: Rust
CODE:
```
// This is the implementation struct for our custom button with added state and functionality.

use glib::object_subclass;
use gtk::prelude::*;
use gtk::subclass::prelude::*;
use std::cell::RefCell;

// Object holding the state
#[derive(Debug, Default)]
pub struct CustomButton {
    number: RefCell<u64>,
}

// The central trait that makes this struct a subclass of a GObject
#[glib::object_subclass]
impl ObjectSubclass for CustomButton {
    const NAME: &'static str = "MyGtkAppCustomButton";
    type Type = super::CustomButton;
    type ParentType = gtk::Button;
}

// Trait for object methods
impl ObjectImpl for CustomButton {
    fn constructed(&self) {
        self.parent_constructed();
        // Call construct in case it is implemented by our parent

        let obj = self.obj();
        obj.set_label(&format!("{}", self.number.borrow()));
    }
}

// Trait for button methods
impl ButtonImpl for CustomButton {
    fn clicked(&self) {
        // Increment the number
        *self.number.borrow_mut() += 1;
        // Update label
        let obj = self.obj();
        obj.set_label(&format!("{}", self.number.borrow()));
    }
}

```

TITLE: Initial GTK App with Lifetime Error (Rust)
DESCRIPTION: This Rust code defines a basic GTK application with a single button. It attempts to increment a local mutable variable `number` within the `connect_clicked` signal handler for the button. This code fails to compile because the closure borrows `number`, which does not have a 'static lifetime required by GTK signal handlers. It depends on the `gtk` and `glib` crates.

```
#use gtk::prelude::*;
#use gtk::{self, glib, Application, ApplicationWindow, Button};
#
#const APP_ID: &str = "org.gtk_rs.GObjectMemoryManagement0";
#
// DOES NOT COMPILE!
fn main() -> glib::ExitCode {
    // Create a new application
    let app = Application::builder().application_id(APP_ID).build();

    // Connect to "activate" signal of `app`
    app.connect_activate(build_ui);

    // Run the application
    app.run()
}

fn build_ui(application: &Application) {
    // Create two buttons
    let button_increase = Button::builder()
        .label("Increase")
        .margin_top(12)
        .margin_bottom(12)
        .margin_start(12)
        .margin_end(12)
        .build();

    // A mutable integer
    let mut number = 0;

    // Connect callbacks
    // When a button is clicked, `number` should be changed
    button_increase.connect_clicked(|_| number += 1);

    // Create a window
    let window = ApplicationWindow::builder()
        .application(application)
        .title("My GTK App")
        .child(&button_increase)
        .build();

    // Present the window
    window.present();
}
```

```
factory.connect_bind(move |_factory, list_item| {
    // Get integer object from list item

        .item()
        .unwrap()
        .downcast::<super::IntegerObject>()

    // Get label from list item

    // Set the label to the number in integer object
```

```
fn close_request(&self, window: &Self::Type) -> glib::Propagation {
    // Save tasks
    if let Err(err) = self.save_tasks(window) {
        println!("Error saving tasks: {err:?}");
    }
    // Propagate close request
    self.parent_close_request(window)
}

fn save_tasks(&self, window: &Window) -> Result<(), Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
    // Get task list store
    let model = window.tasks();

    // Collect all tasks
    let mut tasks = Vec::new();
    for item in model.iter::<TaskObject>() {
        let task_object = item.unwrap();
        tasks.push(task_object.task_data());
    }

    // Get file path
    let path = utils::data_path();

    // Write tasks to file
    let file = std::fs::File::create(path)?;
    serde_json::to_writer(file, &tasks)?;

    Ok(())
}
```

```
fn main() {
    let application = gtk::Application::new(Some("com.example.css"), Default::default());

        provider.load_from_path("style.css").expect("Failed to load CSS");
        gtk::StyleContext::add_provider_for_screen(
            &gdk::Screen::default().expect("Could not get default screen."),

        button1.set_widget_name("button-1");
        hbox.append(&button1);

        let button2 = gtk::Button::with_label("Button 2");
        hbox.append(&button2);

        window.set_child(Some(&hbox));
        window.show();
    });
    application.run();
}
```

```
factory.connect_bind(move |_factory, list_item| {
    // Get integer object from list item

        .item()
        .unwrap()
        .downcast::<super::IntegerObject>()
        .unwrap();

    // Get label from list item
    let label = list_item.child().unwrap().downcast::<gtk::Label>().unwrap();

    // Set the label to the number in integer object
    label.set_label(&integer_object.number().to_string());
```

TITLE: Implementing Data Restoration Function in Rust

```
pub fn restore_data(&self) {
    // Get path
    let path = utils::data_path();

    // Open file with saved tasks
    let file = match std::fs::File::open(path) {
        Ok(file) => file,
        Err(err) => {
            println!("Error: Could not load tasks: {err:?}");
            return;
        }
    };

    // Deserialize tasks from file
    let tasks: Vec<TaskData> = match serde_json::from_reader(file) {
        Ok(tasks) => tasks,
        Err(err) => {
            println!("Error: Could not read tasks from file: {err:?}");
            return;
        }
    };

    // Create new TaskObject for each task
    for task_data in tasks.into_iter() {
        // Create new task object
        let task_object = TaskObject::new(task_data.completed, &task_data.content);

        // Add task object to model
        self.tasks().append(&task_object);
    }
}
```

```
use glib::ParamSpecInt;
use gtk::glib;
use gtk::prelude::*
;
use std::cell::Cell;

#[derive(Default)]
pub struct IntegerObject {
    pub number: Cell<i32>,
}

#[glib::object_subclass(template)]
impl ObjectSubclass for IntegerObject {
    const NAME: &'static str = "IntegerObject";
    type Type = super::IntegerObject;
    type ParentType = glib::Object;

    fn properties() -> &'static [glib::ParamSpec] {
        use once_cell::sync::Lazy;
        static PROPERTIES: Lazy<Vec<glib::ParamSpec>> = Lazy::new(|| {
            vec![
                ParamSpecInt::new(
                    "number",
                    "Number",
                    "The number of the integer object",
                    i32::MIN,
                    i32::MAX,
                    0,
                    glib::ParamFlags::READWRITE,
                )
                .upcast(),
            ]
        });
        PROPERTIES.as_ref()
    }

    fn set_property(&self, _obj: &Self::Type, _id: usize, value: &glib::Value, pspec: &glib::ParamSpec) {
        match pspec.name() {
            "number" => {
                let number = value.get().expect("type conformity checked beforehand");
                self.number.set(number);
            }
            _ => unimplemented!(),
        };
    }

    fn property(&self, _obj: &Self::Type, _id: usize, pspec: &glib::ParamSpec) -> glib::Value {
        match pspec.name() {
            "number" => self.number.get().to_value(),
            _ => unimplemented!(),
        }
    }
}

impl ObjectImpl for IntegerObject {
    fn constructed(&self, obj: &Self::Type) {
        self.parent_constructed(obj);

        // set accessible role
        obj.update_accessible_role(gtk::AccessibleRole::Listitem);
    }
}
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/gtk-rs/gtk4-rs/blob/main/book/src/list_widgets.md#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
use glib::Object;
use gtk::glib;

mod imp;

glue::wrapper! {
    pub struct IntegerObject(Object);

    type Instance = glue::InstanceStruct<imp::IntegerObject>;
    type Class = glue::ClassStruct<imp::IntegerObjectClass>;

    impl {
        pub fn new(number: i32) -> Self {
            Object::new(&[("number", &number)]).expect("Failed to create IntegerObject")
        }

        pub fn number(&self) -> i32 {
            self.imp().number.get()
        }

        pub fn set_number(&self, number: i32) {
            self.imp().number.set(number);
        }

        pub fn increase_number(&self) {
            self.set_number(self.number() + 1);
        }
    }
}

```

TITLE: Implementing Orientation Action with String Parameters in GTK4-rs
DESCRIPTION: Creates an action that changes the orientation of a GtkBox between horizontal and vertical modes. The action has a string parameter and string state, which helps the menu display the current orientation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/gtk-rs/gtk4-rs/blob/main/book/src/actions.md#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: rust
CODE:
```
// Create action for switching orientation
let orientation_action = gio::SimpleAction::new_stateful(
    "orientation",
    Some(&String::static_variant_type()),
    &"Vertical".to_variant(),
);
orientation_action.connect_activate(glib::clone!(@weak self as window => move |action, parameter| {
    let parameter = parameter.unwrap();
    action.set_state(parameter.clone());

    let orientation = match parameter.get::<String>().unwrap().as_str() {
        "Horizontal" => gtk::Orientation::Horizontal,
        "Vertical" => gtk::Orientation::Vertical,
        _ => unreachable!(),
    };
    window.gtk_box().set_orientation(orientation);
}));
self.add_action(&orientation_action);
```
